text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 1.15.1.2 - Records Management as it Relates to Other Programs - Updated reference to the National Distribution Center (NDC) changing from Document 7130, National Distribution Center (NDC) Product Catalog (obsolete as of 07/2017) to IRM 1.18.5, National Distribution Center (NDC).
IRM 1.15.1.3 - Oversight Responsibilities - Added the Business Unit Information Resource Coordinators (BU/IRCs).

IRM 1.15.1.3.2 - Responsibilities of the PGLD Records Specialist Manager - Updated the responsibilities listed for the PGLD Records Specialist Manager. Added reference to Form 14377-A, IRS Records and Information Evaluation Checklist.

IRM 1.15.1.3.3 - Responsibilities of the RIM Records Specialist - Updated the responsibilities listed for the RIM Records Specialist. Added reference to Form 14377-A, IRS Records and Information Evaluation Checklist.
IRM 1.15.1.3.4 - Responsibilities of Headquarters Business Unit IRCs - Changed the subsection title and updated the responsibilities of the Business Unit Information Resource Coordinator (BU/IRC).
IRM 1.15.1.3.5 - Responsibilities of the Information Resource Coordinator (IRC) - Updated the responsibilities listed for the Information Resource Coordinator.
1.15.1.3.6 - Responsibilities of All IRS Employees and Contractors - Updated the responsibilities for All IRS Employees and Contractors.

IRM references, website links, editorial updates, and word revisions in compliance with the Plain Writing Act have been made throughout this IRM section. Also changed references from Enterprise Learning Management System (ELMS) to Integrated Talent Management (ITM) throughout.
All IRS divisions and functions
of Contents
of the National Archives and Records Administration
Information Management Program
page (

) Purpose: This section describes the Records and Information Management (RIM) Program, as an integral function within the IRS, as well as the roles responsibilities of those employees who manage the program. Records and information management is the application of systematic controls to all recorded information that the IRS generates as original documentation and subsequently requires in order to conduct business. This recorded tion falls under the statutory deﬁnition of “Federal Records”. Records are considered media (or format) neutral. Consequently, procedures for records and information management apply to official IRS recorded information in all format types. See Title
U.S. Code (USC)
) for a deﬁnition of “Records Management”, and
for a deﬁnition of “Federal Records”. (

) The program scope consists of managing the entire life cycle of records, re- gardless of format (e.g. paper, digital, audio, photographic, micrographic, cartographic, geo-spatial); that is, creation or receipt, maintenance, disposal (destruction), retirement or transfer of (permanent) records to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), including regional archives NARA-managed satellite archives. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to ALL IRS employees and contractors. (

) Program Owner: The Records and Information Management (RIM) Program office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the Servicewide records manage- ment policy. (
) In keeping with the Federal Records Act of
, as amended, and pursuant Title
, USC

, the IRS established a records management program - renamed Records and Information Management (RIM) Program - to ensure economical and efficient management of its records. The program provides the application, on a continuing basis, of sound management practices and techniques in the creation, maintenance, retrieval, preservation, and of all records. (

) The mission of the RIM Program is to provide guidance and oversee related functions and processes which ensure that IRS records are available where and when they are needed, to whom they are needed, for only as long as are needed, in order to conduct business, adequately document IRS and protect the interests of the federal government and the American All IRS records are required under statute to be efficiently managed until disposition. The RIM Program ensures this requirement. Major goals of the program are to furnish accurate and complete information when required to manage and operate the organization, and to provide information and storage at the lowest possible cost. These goals are accomplished by: a. Creating only necessary records while minimizing ﬁling of duplicates; b. Organizing and controlling records efficiently through inventories and planning; c. Storing and managing records cost effectively through the use of elec- tronic and local ﬁles area storage, and NARA-operated Federal Centers (FRC); and

Records and information management is the application of systematic controls to all recorded information that the IRS generates as original documentation and subsequently requires in order to conduct business. This recorded tion falls under the statutory deﬁnition of “Federal Records”. Records are considered media (or format) neutral. , Correspondence Manual. b. Files Management includes proper maintenance, selection, retrieval, retention, and disposition of ﬁles. Guidelines for managing ﬁles are contained in IRM

, Files Management. Reminder: Accurate ﬁles management is a sound foundation of a good recordkeeping system. c. Publishing Management involves the printing and publishing of IRS documents. Since most documents are ultimately record-related, proper retention and disposition procedures are especially important to this program. Coordinate with the Multimedia Publishing staff, the Records Officer, and the RIM staff to ensure the proper recordkeeping practices are met.
Publishing Management involves the printing and publishing of IRS documents. Since most documents are ultimately record

related, proper retention and disposition procedures are especially important to this program. Coordinate with the Multimedia Publishing staff, the Servicewide Records Officer, and the RIM staff to ensure the proper recordkeeping practices are met.
Note: Guidelines on Publishing Management are included in IRM 1.17.

The Records and Information Management Program

c. Plans, schedules, administers, directs, prioritizes, and conducts major RIM operations throughout the IRS; d. Plans, directs and conducts comprehensive and long-range projects or studies of records and information management practices; e. Serves as senior liaison for the IRS with NARA, the Department of the Treasury, other government agencies, and private industry on all and information management matters that impact upon the entire IRS; f. Serves as the IRS Records Management Officer under Treasury (TD)

; g. Develops new records control schedules and reviews existing (at least annually) based on any necessary changes consistent with IRS procedures and legal requirements; h. Participates in records reviews, program evaluations, special studies, task forces, etc., in Headquarters and ﬁeld organizations; i. Provides technical guidance and assistance in fostering the mission of RIM Program; j. Advises Records Specialists of new initiatives which will require an unplanned increase in the retiring and servicing of records at the FRCs; k. Reviews Systems of Records Notices (SORN) and Privacy and Civil Liberties Impact Assessments (PCLIA) prior to publication for appropriate disposition treatment; l. Provides oversight and monitoring of Records Center Program (RCP) services and all off-site NARA-held holdings of IRS records, using various tools provided by the Archives and Records Center Information System (ARCIS); m. Certiﬁes for payment of all NARA invoices for RCP services invoiced for administrative, policy, and program records; n. Transfers permanent records to NARA; o. Promotes awareness and understanding of records and information man- agement through training, publicity, and related support activities; and p. Provides oversight and monitoring of disposition of electronic records of the IRS at all organizational levels using Capital Planning and Investment Control (CPIC) strategies, and advising on E-
language, participating the Enterprise Life Cycle (ELC) process, and using electronic records management tools.
(02-05-2021) Responsibilities of the PGLD Records Specialist Manager

a. Ensures that the IRS business unit organizations coordinate annual contact with the Business Unit (BU) IRCs for the purpose of assessing program records and information management compliance. This ance includes, but is not limited to, BU assignment of IRCs to conduct periodic inventories, complete annual ﬁles planning activities, complete quarterly Form

-A , IRS Records and Information Evaluation Checklist, and carry out other associated duties as required; b. Ensures that Posts of Duty (PODs) and BUs in area of coverage designate IRC responsibilities to identiﬁable staff and communicate mation effectively to the Records Specialist. The assignment of IRCs requirement in the Annual Management Control Accountability Process (MCAP); c. Designates Records Specialists who serve as the primary responsible official(s) for directing and advising management and employees on
Records Specialists who serve as the primary responsible for directing and advising management and employees on
1.15 Records and Information Management
and requirements for PODs within their area of coverage, ensuring safeguards are in place for both physical and elec-

including ensuring safeguards are in place for both physical and elec- tronic records management; Advises the IRS Records Officer of the designated Records Specialists; Oversees and supports the Records Specialist Team on all their roles and responsibilities as outlined in IRM

; Serves as the IRS Super-Administrator Archival Records Center Informa- tion System (ARCIS), and grants/removes access to, trains users, resets passwords, and approves input requests into the ARCIS system; and Serves as the IRS NARA/FRC Liaison who oversees all IRS/FRC activi- ties; resolves all issues in the FRCs with the IRS/NARA account representative and FRC Directors; completes and certiﬁes the FRC monthly billing reports; completes and submits the quarterly FRC disposal reports to the FRCs.
d. Advises the IRS Records Officer of the designated Records Specialists; e. Oversees and supports the Records Specialist Team on all their roles and responsibilities as outlined in IRM

; f. Serves as the IRS Super-Administrator Archival Records Center Informa- tion System (ARCIS), and grants/removes access to, trains users, resets passwords, and approves input requests into the ARCIS system; and g. Serves as the IRS NARA/FRC Liaison who oversees all IRS/FRC activi- ties; resolves all issues in the FRCs with the IRS/NARA account representative and FRC Directors; completes and certiﬁes the FRC monthly billing reports; completes and submits the quarterly FRC disposal reports to the FRCs. The Records Specialist Manager designates the Records Specialist who: a. Assists the IRS Records Officer in implementing an effective RIM Pro- gram; b. Maintains a contact directory of the designated IRC assigned for the IRS functional organizations within area of coverage and ensures the accu- racy of the IRC contacts on a quarterly basis. Reviews the IRS Directory to identify the functional organizations in order to verify/obtain IRCs for area of coverage; c. Conducts and/or participates in RIM Program activities, ensuring the ad- equate and timely training of IRCs and local IRS personnel in federal re- cords management requirements. This includes, but is not limited to, site assistance or virtual visits to PODs in their area of coverage to assess records conditions and provide related support, Continuing Professional Education (CPE) training courses, and attention to new IRCs in need of baseline records management assistance. See Form

-A, IRS Re- cords and Information Evaluation Checklist; a quarterly evaluation list ﬁlled in by all Business Units to identify potential training needs and provide recommendations based on their responses; d. Certiﬁes to the IRS Records Officer completion of the Integrated Talent Management (ITM), Course Number

, Introduction to Records agement for Information Resource Coordinators, within three months of appointment; e. Annually coordinates and assists IRCs and local offices in the conduct records inventories for their area of coverage; f. Evaluates records management problems and resolves local ones which need attention, and forwards resolution to the IRS Records Officer. all Servicewide problems to the IRS Records Officer for resolution; g. Participates in local area or local business function studies and recom- mends actions to improve the RIM Program; h. Assists customers in establishing and developing disposition information for revising or updating existing records control schedules or developing new records series, including the identiﬁcation of new or revised disposi- tion authorities for electronic information systems. Coordinates with and/or advises the IRS Records Officer, as appropriate; i. Serves as liaisons with NARA FRC and IRS BU (including campus ﬁles activities) on records disposition matters, including the retirement, re- trieval, and coordination of disposal activities;
The Records and Information Management Program

j. Reviews and approves all records retirements, transfers, retrievals, and disposals. Tracks and monitors records requests to and from the FRCs. Develop monthly billing reports; k. Assists others in fostering the mission of the RIM Program; l. Promotes awareness of records management through training, publicity, and related support activities. Ensures an annual Communications Plan approved by the IRS Records Officer; m. Maintains documentation of all assigned RIM Program activities in the area of coverage, including but not limited to, records transfer and re- trieval forms, disposal notices, ﬁles plans, training ﬁles, program promo- tion materials, communications plans, and comprehensive listing of n. Assists customers in implementing and improving methods in the storage, access, retrieval, preservation and disposal of documents and other information; o. Assists offices in the area to mitigate disasters affecting records; p. Assists customers in selecting suitable media for information or data they collect and store; q. Participates in Servicewide studies having records component; r. Conducts annual reviews of IRS and POD to ensure compliance with responsibilities, including training, records inventories and ﬁles planning activities, and veriﬁcation that records control schedules continue to meet customers’ program and administrative needs. This is accomplished through the quarterly distribution of Form

-A, IRS Records and mation Evaluation Checklist; s. Participates in space planning activities to effect efficient storage and en- sure compliance with IRS and Department of the Treasury records man- agement requirements; t. Reviews purchase requests and use of records equipment and supplies effect efficient storage and ensure compliance with IRS and Department the Treasury records management requirements; u. Identiﬁes permanent records in area of coverage for transfer to NARA; v. Ensures timely completion of all annual and periodic ITM learning plan quirements for the RIM Program.

Reminder: The IRS Records Officer and all Records Specialists are authorized to inspect IRS records, related paperwork, and any indexes, box listings, or shipping documents and procedures to conﬁrm the use of appropri- ate retention and disposal authorities and that program objectives are

Caution: Although Records Specialists have access to IRS records, their inspec- tion of investigative records is limited. The inspection cannot include the examination of the contents of individual investigative case ﬁles including, but not limited to, those that are Grand Jury or involve undercover or co- vert operations (including informants). The only legitimate access to indi- vidual investigative case ﬁles is allowable when appraising records, determining compliance with retention requirements, or administering In- ternal Revenue Code Section
) activities as required.
See Form 14377-A, IRS Records and Information Evaluation Checklist, for ad- ditional information on ensuring an efficient and effective RIM Program.
Records and Information Management

) Each IRS Headquarters organization/Business Unit is responsible for designat- ing a primary Business Unit Information Resource Coordinator (BU/IRC), point of contact for records, and advising the Records Specialist and IRS Records Officer. This BU/IRC acts as the main contact for the IRS Records Officer when dealing with RIM issues across a single business or organizational unit. Differences in scheduling new records or any changes that must be made to an existing RCS that affects an entire BU will be coordinated through this individual. The BU/IRC is the records representative for his or her functional organization and may speak or act with full authority within the organization. This person should not be confused with the (local) IRC who is responsible for records activities within their function/organization, Post Of Duty.
Example: The Headquarters BU/IRC is appointed and directed by the Commis- sioner, Deputy Commissioner, or Chief, for a Division or Office and re- ports directly to an Executive.

) Each BU/IRC: a. Assists the IRS Records Officer and the Records Specialist in ing an effective RIM Program; b. Identiﬁes new or revised records series and recommends retention and disposal time frames to their Records Specialist and the IRS Records Officer; c. Assists in the coordination of records inventories for the business unit and supports the activity working with the Records Specialist and the Records Officer to get the annual inventory and ﬁles plan accomplished; d. Certiﬁes to their Records Specialist completion of the ITM, Course Number

, Introduction to Records Management for Information Resource Coordinators, within three months of appointment; e. Brings issues to the attention of the Records Specialist and IRS Officer; and f. Assists in the coordination of records disposal approvals/disapprovals the Business Unit. (

) Each IRS functional organization, i.e., POD or functional BU (in the case of larger activities) is required to designate an Information Resource (IRC) to be responsible for local records activities and is required to notify Records Specialists Manager and Records Specialist of changes to assign- ment as they occur. At least once annually, BU managers must provide organizational and contact information to their local Records Specialist. This information is necessary to update records servicing authorities and to the systemic control over local records processes (e.g. the annual ﬁles plan- ning process, and periodic records inventorying). (

) IRCs are required to notify their local Records Specialist of any new records that must be scheduled or any changes that must be made to their existing RCS. In addition, the IRC is responsible for assisting the local Records Spe- cialists in implementing an effective RIM Program within their function/ organization. The IRC is the records liaison representative for his or her functional organization and may speak or act with full authority within the organization. At a minimum there should be one IRC in every POD where a BU is located. However, for small PODs where there is only a shared office, there should be at least one local IRC who may not be in that POD, but lo- cated in the same area with oversight of that office. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F

a. Assists the IRS Records Officer and the Records Specialist in ing an effective RIM Program; b. Identiﬁes new or revised records series and recommends retention and disposal time frames to their Records Specialist and the IRS Records Officer; c. Assists in the coordination of records inventories for the business unit and supports the activity working with the Records Specialist and the Records Officer to get the annual inventory and ﬁles plan d. Certiﬁes to their Records Specialist completion of the ITM, Course Number

, Introduction to Records Management for Information Resource Coordinators, within three months of appointment; e. Brings issues to the attention of the Records Specialist and IRS Officer; and f. Assists in the coordination of records disposal approvals/disapprovals the Business Unit.

) Each IRS functional organization, i.e., POD or functional BU (in the case of larger activities) is required to designate an Information Resource (IRC) to be responsible for local records activities and is required to notify Records Specialists Manager and Records Specialist of changes to ment as they occur. At least once annually, BU managers must provide organizational and contact information to their local Records Specialist. information is necessary to update records servicing authorities and to the systemic control over local records processes (e.g. the annual ﬁles ning process, and periodic records inventorying). (

) IRCs are required to notify their local Records Specialist of any new that must be scheduled or any changes that must be made to their existing RCS. In addition, the IRC is responsible for assisting the local Records cialists in implementing an effective RIM Program within their function/ organization. The IRC is the records liaison representative for his or her functional organization and may speak or act with full authority within the organization. At a minimum there should be one IRC in every POD where BU is located. However, for small PODs where there is only a shared there should be at least one local IRC who may not be in that POD, but lo- cated in the same area with oversight of that office.
(02-05-2021) Responsibilities of the Information Resource Coordinator (IRC)
Records and Information Management Program 1.15.1 page
Example: A functional organization may be an Assistant Commissioner, Area, Divi- sion, Office, BU, POD, or Section.

a. Assists employees with records disposition and inventory questions; b. Develops and/or reviews local ﬁles plans at least annually and them to their local Records Specialist; c. Certiﬁes to their Records Specialist completion of the ITM, Course Number

, Introduction to Records Management for Information Resource Coordinators, within three months of appointment; d. Conducts periodic inventories necessary to validate ﬁles plans and identify new records series (new types of records not identiﬁed in the RCSs); e. Coordinates the approval for the disposal of records in their area of coverage; f. Maintains documentation on disposed records, records retirements transfers, retrievals, and ﬁles plans; g. Plans orderly disposition of inactive records in compliance with control schedules, IRS and Department of the Treasury policies, and Federal regulations; h. Ensures that records eligible for storage at a FRC are packed in boxes and that Standard Form (SF)

, Records Transmittal and ceipt, and required box listing is accurately prepared; i. Identiﬁes new or revised records series and recommends retention disposal time frames to the Records Specialist; and j. Brings other issues or concerns to the attention of the Records or the IRS Records Officer.
Note: Local IRC activities are collateral duties.
Each IRS employee and contractor must:
1.15.1.3.6 (02-05-2021) Responsibilities of All IRS Employees and Contractors
a. Manage the records they create and/or maintain in accordance with policies outlined in IRM
through IRM

; b. Assure the integrity and conﬁdentiality of the records in their custody and with which they use to do their jobs. Managers are responsible for ensuring that their employees comply with these requirements; c. Return records requested from the FRC promptly when ﬁnished with the records; d. Certify the completion of the ITM, Course Number

, Records Man- agement Mandatory Brieﬁng; and e. Work with local IRCs to the extent possible to resolve records and infor- mation management issues (local IRCs will confer with their designated Records Specialists as needed to assist with resolving Employee and Contractors record related issues).
Records and Information Management

) NARA is the oversight agency responsible for appraising all federal records, approving their disposition, providing program assistance, evaluating records of the management programs, and serving as the ﬁnal custodian of permanent and records. FRC operating under an OMB approved reimbursable program as Records Center Program (RCP), are a functional operation within the NARA organization that provide low cost off-site storage of records to all federal agencies. (

) NARA operates two different types of records facilities: a. FRCs provide temporary storage and reference services for records are needed infrequently by the customer but are not yet eligible for disposal or transfer to the National Archives. IRS records stored in an FRC remain in the legal custody of the IRS. b. NARA permanently preserves select historical IRS records or IRS records of continuing value (e.g. rights and interests) permanently. Only small percentage of these records have been identiﬁed and are scheduled as “PERMANENT” in the IRS RCS, speciﬁcally RCS

transferring permanent records to NARA, the IRS transfers all legal custody of those records to NARA. NARA ensures preservation of permanent records and provides reference service to the IRS and its customers. NARA will withhold information that is restricted under (e.g. Internal Revenue Code Section
) from the public. Note: The IRS must identify all records access and use restrictions for NARA on official transfer documentation (i.e., SF
Agreement to Transfer Records to the National Archives of the United States). (
) Other functions of NARA include the offering of records management training

Other functions of NARA include the offering of records management training courses, issuing the GRS, and establishing standards for media preservation.
